title: Solosmasthana
data: Built during the lifetime of Buddha , it is the first ever stupa to be constructed in Sri Lanka . The temple enshrines a lock of hair given by Buddha to Saman , a local chieftain and later a Buddhist deity , during his first visit to the island , 9 months after attaining enlightenment

Constructed by the two warring Naga kings , Chulodara and Mahodara , on the site where Buddha , during his second visit to Sri Lanka , intervened and mediated in settling a dispute over the possession of a gem-studded throne . This throne was later enshrined in this stupa
Built by Naga king Maniakkika , the temple , hallowed during the third and final visit of Buddha to Sri Lanka enshrines a gem studded throne on which the Buddha sat and preached
The sacred left footprint imprinted by Buddha on his third visit to Sri Lanka at the apex of the mountain . Vijayabahu I first built resting houses for pilgrims during his reign
Natural . The cave in which Buddha spent the day after placing his footprint on Sri Pada . The place is yet unidentified
Constructed by Saddha Tissa enshrining relics of the Buddha , at the site where Buddha spent sometime with Arhants absorbed in ecstatic meditation , during his final visit
Erected by Devanampiya Tissa enshrining relics of Buddha . The site has been consecrated by Lord Buddha , who spent a few moments absorbed in ecstatic meditation
Built by Kavan Tissa it is one of the largest stupas in Ruhuna . The Silpasena Pirivena has been at this site
Tissamaharama , Southern Province 6°17′00″N 81°17′00″E / 6.28333°N 81.28333°E / 6.28333 ; 81.28333 ( Tissamaharama Raja Maha Vihara )
Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi ජය ශ්‍රී මහා බොධිය
The southern branch from the Bodhi Tree at Bodh Gaya under which Buddha attained Enlightenment . Planted during the reign of Devanampiya Tissa
Anuradhapura , North Central Province 8°20′41″N 80°23′48″E / 8.34472°N 80.39667°E / 8.34472 ; 80.39667 ( Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi )
Built by Dutugamunu with the relic studded sceptre of the King deposited in the stupa
Anuradhapura , North Central Province 8°20′42″N 80°23′20″E / 8.34500°N 80.38889°E / 8.34500 ; 80.38889 ( Mirisawetiya Vihara )
Built by Dutugamunu over an impressive collection of relics
A relic shrine , the original structure was built by Devanampiya Tissa . The temple built to contain the right Clavicle of Buddha

Constructed on the site of a Jaina temple by Valagamba to commemorate the reconquering of the kingdom from foreign usurpers who had deposed him and occupied the throne for 15 year . The stupa enshrines relics of Buddha and the Tripitaka inscribed in gold leaves
Anuradhapura , North Central Province 8°21′00″N 80°23′00″E / 8.35000°N 80.38333°E / 8.35000 ; 80.38333 ( Abhayagiri vihāra )
Construction begun by Mahasena and finished by his successor Sirimeghavanna . The waist-band used by Buddha is said to be enshrined
Lanja Tissa . The site where Arahat Mahinda Thero met Devanampiya Tissa and converted him to Buddhism . The Urna Roma , the sacred hair relic between the eyebrows , is said to be enshrined in here

First built by King Mahasena , the temple enshirnes the golden seat , from which Buddha delivered a sermon , a lock of hair and the royal sword ( magul kaduwa ) used by Prince Siddhartha to cut off his hair at the time of the Great Renunciation
intro: 'Solosmasthana' are 16 sacred places in Sri Lanka, believed by Buddhists to have been hallowed by visits of Gautama Buddha. These places of worship are among the most important religious locations in Sri Lanka, and are located throughout the country. Ancient Buddhist and historical sources of Sri Lanka assert that the Buddha visited the country on three occasions. These three visits are given in some detail in the ancient chronicle Mahavamsa, which describes his journeys to eleven of the Solosmasthana. Other sources such as the Pujavaliya, Samantapasadika and Butsarana also mention these visits.
